claim: In the U.K., you can protect yourself against claims of copyright infringement by not making any money off the copyrighted work.

supporting.text: Under U.K. copyright law, infringement occurs when a substantial part of a copyrighted work is used without permission, regardless of whether the user profits from it.

attacks.text: Under U.K. copyright law, infringement occurs when a substantial part of a copyrighted work is used without permission, regardless of whether the user profits from it.
Non-commercial use may be considered fair dealing under U.K. law, which can exempt certain uses from being infringement.
Fair dealing exemptions are narrowly defined and do not cover all non-commercial uses, especially if the use competes with the original work's market.
Some U.K. court rulings have treated non-commercial use more leniently, even if technically infringing, reducing legal consequences.
Leniency in past rulings does not establish a legal precedent strong enough to reliably protect against infringement claims.

supporting.text: The U.K. Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 does not exempt non-commercial use from infringement; it only considers the nature of the copying and its effect on the copyright holder.

attacks.text: The U.K. Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 does not exempt non-commercial use from infringement; it only considers the nature of the copying and its effect on the copyright holder.
Some U.K. court rulings have interpreted 'fair dealing' exceptions to include non-commercial uses, such as private study or research, effectively providing limited protection.
The 'fair dealing' exceptions are narrowly defined and do not broadly cover all non-commercial uses, leaving many cases of infringement unprotected.
The U.K. Intellectual Property Office guidelines suggest that non-commercial use may reduce penalties, even if infringement is still technically established.
Reduced penalties do not equate to legal protection; the act of infringement remains unlawful regardless of commercial intent.

supporting.text: Fair dealing exceptions in the U.K. allow limited use of copyrighted material without permission, but these exceptions are based on purpose (e.g., research, criticism) rather than financial gain.

attacks.text: Fair dealing exceptions in the U.K. allow limited use of copyrighted material without permission, but these exceptions are based on purpose (e.g., research, criticism) rather than financial gain.
While fair dealing is purpose-based, courts often consider commercial use as a factor in determining whether a use is fair, making financial gain indirectly relevant.
The U.K. Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 explicitly lists 'non-commercial research' as a fair dealing purpose, showing that financial intent can influence exceptions.
Some fair dealing purposes, such as parody or criticism, may still involve incidental financial gain without invalidating the exception.
Even in parody or criticism, excessive commercial exploitation can lead courts to rule against fair dealing, reinforcing the relevance of financial intent.

supporting.text: Legal precedent in the U.K. has established that even non-commercial use can constitute infringement if it conflicts with the normal exploitation of the work or unreasonably prejudices the copyright holder.

attacks.text: Legal precedent in the U.K. has established that even non-commercial use can constitute infringement if it conflicts with the normal exploitation of the work or unreasonably prejudices the copyright holder.
Many U.K. copyright cases explicitly require commercial intent or financial gain to establish infringement, especially in fair dealing exceptions.
The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 includes specific exceptions for non-commercial research, private study, and parody, which do not require financial harm to the copyright holder.
Even under fair dealing exceptions, courts may rule against non-commercial use if it significantly impacts the market for the original work, as seen in cases like Ashdown v Telegraph Group Ltd.
